bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, September 2, 1955

div1.p: Hench is concerned about the status of Camp Lazear, and wants anything done that would expedite its becoming a museum.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, September 2, 1955
div1.opener:
September 2, 1955
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I shall be interested to see you in Philadelphia and go over your discoveries
with respect to the old American cemetery and I will certainly try to re-
member to bring with me your previous correspondence thereon.

I have not quite finished my Philadelphia talk because Tocantins has not told
me what to omit to avoid over-lapping.

With respect to your item #3, let me put your mind at rest at once. Pedro,
you and I have had such a happy and sympathetic relationship that you must
know I would never do anything intentionally to hurt you or your colleagues
or do anything important behind your back. The situation is this.

First and flatly, your informant, whoever he is, is almost 100% wrong but
whatever truth there is in it is as follows: You may remember that several
years ago, in order to try to stimulate the preservation of Camp Lazear (long
before your influence in this behalf began to be felt in Cuba and long before
the patronates were organized), I got an informal promise of $10,000 from the
Mayo Clinic through Mr. Harry Harwick who was then the head of the Executive
Department and, in some ways, the informal “head of the Clinic.” This was in
the days before I knew you very well and I think most of my contacts were with
and through General Ramos. I was permitted to make that tentative offer of
support in a letter to someone and later noticed that the offer was published
in the Havana newspapers. Those were the days that Johnny Moran was my main
associate. But nothing happened.

Some time later, after the camp-site had been made a national monument, but
before anything was done to preserve it, I visited the Vice-President of Cuba
and during a conversation, offered him my own personal check for $1,000 just
to have the privilege of having a correugated iron protection put around the
caseta until such time as the Cuban Government would protect it. But my offer
was politely refused. Nothing more happened until you organized the patrons.

Since then, Mr. Harwick has retired and I must confess the spirit of our
Executive Department is now somewhat less generous and more realistic and
whether the Clinic would renew this offer, I frankly do not know. I intend
to find out in the near future but must handle the matter diplomatically.
I should first see Mr. Harwick because if he, though retired, could speak
for me and have the Executive Department of the Clinic reactivate this offer,
that would be by far the best.
Dr. Pedro Nogueira - 2 - September 2, 1955

The simple reason that the Clinic is less generous now in all such extra-
mural contributions is that we have had to build a $14,000,000 building,
just completed a year ago, which I imagine is not yet paid for, and even
more important, the extra facilities have required a fairly large expan-
sion of personnel. Therefore, like all sensible institutions, the Clinic
has been retrenching in less important expenditures and we are going
through a period of “careful expenditures,” to speak mildly. This has
been fairly extensive and has involved actually the reorganization of two
or three ancillary departments - research departments which had little or
no direct contact with clinical medicine. Therefore a gift of $10,000
today for this project would be reviewed much more carefully than when it
was previously made. I do not actually know that the offer has been can-
celled or would not be renewed but I imagine, under the circumstances, it has
just lapsed by default.

This is the extent of any information I have regarding any “thousands of
dollars” from the Clinic for any project whatever.

During the many years that I have been trying to do something about Camp
Lazear, I made numerous contacts. Most of them were pleasant but relatively
unprofitable. For example, in earlier years, I occasionally contacted Doctor
Carbonell who, in his own time, was helpful and it was he who got me
to see the Vice-President. In the last two or three years, I have only seen
him socially and have not discussed any moves with respect to Camp Lazear.
Now, as you know, I have been planning to develop, at the appropriate time,
a committee of what might be called the “American Friends of Camp Lazear,”
but three things have prevented the organization of this group to date.
First, because of the long Cuban delays, I had nothing tangible to propose
to such an American group. Since I could not even myself spend $1,000 to
protect the “national monument”, there was no use for me to interest any
Americans as the legalization of the caseta as a national monument, tem-
porarily at least, prevented any private contributions or suggestions.

Secondly, the war began just as I was starting correspondence with Fishbein
and others in the American Medical Association with respect to the formation
of such a group and, third, cortisone hit and has preoccupied me intensely
ever since.

The main reason, however, that I have not gotten back to this project is be-
cause I have not been sure of myself and of just what any outside group could
propose or do for Camp Lazear. Although you and I have discussed this often
in general terms, actually, Pedro, you and I have never gotten down to “brass
tacks” and this you and I must do in the near future. Meanwhile the various
contacts I previously made in Cuba have entertained me socially from time to
time and we have always discussed the support of the Camp Lazear project but
in very general terms. The contacts have included Tom Spies and Mrs. Louise
Smith, chiefly, and various friends of theirs.

Confidentially, Pedro, at the time I came to Havana for the Nutrition Congress
about two or three years ago, I found three groups pulling me, pleasantly, in
three different directions. You and your developing group were by far the
most important, indeed the only important group, but Tom Spies had some ideas
of his own and Mrs. Smith had some ideas. The latter were interested because
Dr. Pedro Nogueira - 3 - September 2, 1955
they weren't yet sure that you and your associates were actually going to be
able to do anything. I allowed myself to explore various ideas with these
friends without committing myself to anything. These friends were quite un-
selfish and merely wanted to help in case the Cuban Government did nothing.
You can be positively assured of that. One suggestion was that if the Cuban
Government would do nothing, I would meet with a small group of Mrs. Smith's
friends and perhaps they, with or without the auspices of F.I.M., would help
me raise money and use Camp Lazear as a symbol of Cuban American mutual in-
terest and friendship. Again, I can assure you positively that this was their
only motive and, to the extent that this idea still persists (as I shall men-
tion shortly) that is still their only intention. Of course, let us be frank.
To the extent that these good people, acting purely as local Cuban-American
friends of Camp Lazear or under the general sponsorship of F.I.M., might get
some pleasant and quite bona fide publicity for F.I.M., that would be to the
credit of F.I.M.

Pedro, I have done not one single thing underhandedly. I thought you knew
that Mrs. Smith was interested. I am sure I told you and I suspect that I
have written you a little of this, although I am dictating this from my
office without reviewing any correspondence. In any event, the situation
is simply this. You and I know that much remains to be done at Camp Lazear
to satisfy not others, perhaps, but you and me with our higher ambitions.
I think we both would like to see the caseta under permanent cover, sur-
rounded by an appropriate little museum. We both want the former site of
Building No. 2 purchased, preserved and marked. We both want to have pre-
served enough of the land to stop the encroaching quarries. We both want to
fill up (if not a little museum) at least the inside of the caseta with
photographs, display cabinets, etc. We both want a stone and bronze marker
on the site of Building No. 2 and an explanatory bronze tablet outside the
caseta. The lesser of our larger plan is to have the caseta enclosed in a
little museum and in the rooms thereof a rather complete historical display
to include many items that I have and that you have, and that we may get
from the Finlay family. Under such circumstances, we both want to have
the caseta refurnished as it was in 1901.

The larger phase of our bigger plan would be to connect all of this with a
living memorial, either a public health unit or some other structure (of
which the museum would be an annex) which would be of public service to the
people of Quemados de Marianao. So much for the larger plan.

Some immediate requirements we have discussed include the purchase of the land
in front of the caseta, that is, where Building No. 2 was; the improvement of
the road; the marker at the site of Building No. 2, and the production of a
little souvenir booklet, printed in English and Spanish to be sold at the
caseta, and also the designation of the caseta as a point of historical
interest for tourists and to be mentioned in the various guide books and
tourist weeklies.

As I have discussed these projects in a general way with you (and indeed some
of these were your own ideas or were transmitted to me by Doctor Recio, the
head of the Patronates) so I have discussed them in a friendly way with Tina
and Lydia, also with the American Ambassador on one occasion, and also with
Dr. Pedro Nogueira - 4 - September 2, 1955
Mrs. Smith on one or two occasions. You will remember how interested Mr.
William Caswell was at the time of the dedication. He and Mrs. Smith par-
ticularly, got quite enthusiastic and before I left they called a hasty
little meeting of perhaps eight or ten close friends, all Americans, I
think. It was really a cocktail party for Mary and me but after the drinks,
they asked me to expound on the future plans for Camp Lazear. I talked
quite informally for possibly an hour and mentioned, in general, all of
the above plans, throwing together without discrimination the ideas of
Doctor Recio, of yourself and of me. They expressed strong approval and
if I had not had to leave the next day, I think we might, right then, have
made the first steps toward organizing the Havana Chapter of the American
Friends of Camp Lazear. But it never went beyond the talking stage. This
was about two years ago. I was supposed to correspond with them, write
down the specific details of these projects and hopes and then form a group
in this country which might be called the United States Chapter of the
American Friends, to raise money along with the Havana chapter. The sug-
gestion was made that the Havana Chapter might be expanded to include prominent
and wealthy Cubans so that it would be the Cuban-American Friends of Camp
Lazear, and it was to be mostly a matter of personal solicitation among a
relatively few wealthy people. I can assure you that this was mostly just
enthusiastic talk and that whatever plans we had, when the preliminaries
materialized, were to be submitted to the patrons and that both of these
groups were to be formed solely and entirely to accomplish not only the modest
hopes of the patrons, but to accomplish perhaps their wildest hopes (that is,
really the hopes of you and me). But again, I have been so terribly busy
plus, very confidentially, a borderline nervous exhaustion state (from which
I am fortunately recovering nicely), that I have done practically nothing and
of course my American friends in Havana have done nothing.

Nothing was done except two things. Some time after my last visit with you,
I did write down these various hopes and plans and included them in a report
which I sent to the Walter Reed Memorial Association last November. I pre-
sented the report in person and my main reason was to get the immediate sup-
port of the Surgeon General of the U. S. Army with respect to a few items:
to find for us the old Yldefonso Perez model of the Post Hospital which apparently
is now at Carlisle Barracks and to save it for our museum at Camp Lazear; to
enlist his support so that I might have the Finlay data microfilmed and to
get from him not only some old Army cots of 1900 which might be in some old
Army warehouse and also see if the Surgeon General's Library would finish
translating every one of Finlay's papers.

The second thing I did was not done until a few months ago when Captain and
Mrs. Gawne wrote that they hoped to visit Havana. I bestirred myself and
worked hard several evenings, writing up in a different arrangement and
describing briefly the various places in Havana and Quemados connected with
the yellow fever episode. As it turned out, this revision might well be used,
at least in part, for the little booklet you and I hope to prepare to be sold
at the caseta. I think I sent you copies of these data. I had hoped then
to follow through and send these to Mrs. Smith, Mr. Caswell and others but,
again, I get too involved.

The last chapter of this story now follows. I think it was possibly two or
three months ago that I had a letter either from Tina or from Mrs. Smith, a
purely social letter (my brother and I ran into Tina and Lydia in Paris last
fall). In any event, they reminded me that these American friends were still
Dr. Pedro Nogueira - 5 - September 2, 1955
waiting to hear from me and would be glad to organize whenever I could help
and give them the appropriate information. They expressed the hope that
I might return this next December for Finlay Day and talk to them again, and
that is where it stands.

Now actually, Pedro, as you see, everything up to now has been purely conversa-
tion and, in summary, the embryonic plan is simply in line with what you and I
have so often discussed - for me to form an American branch of the “Friends of
Camp Lazear” (and the Reed family and others have promised to support this when
I get around to it). Second, for you and me to form either a Havana section of
“American Friends of Camp Lazear” or a “Cuban-American Friends of Camp Lazear.”
Third, for these groups to know (from you, Doctor Recio, the Patrons and me)
just what the Patrons can and cannot do and what they would like to have help
on and then for these groups to go out and get the money and to work through
the Patrons for the proper preservation of Camp Lazear plus a living memorial
of some sort.

Now if anybody, unknown to me, has more ideas more expansive than this, for
any other purpose than this or for any selfish purpose and for any purpose
contrary to the wishes of the Patrons, I know absolutely nothing about it and
would not support it if I did. I think you know me well enough, Pedro, to
know that I have no capacity to deceive and certainly not the intention. I
have no doubt that I have talked to many people and have not, perhaps, reported
to you every talk or visit or conversation, but that is simply because I have
continued to do what you and I have been doing together and independently for
several years; namely, to try to find proper support from any and all appropriate
sources in a diplomatic and non-conflicting way. Everything actually is held
in abeyance because you and I, the prime movers, have not yet had the oppor-
tunity to sit down together perhaps with Doctor Recio and decide, first of
all, what the Cuban Government and Patrons can do themselves and what help
they want for projects they would approve. This is the next step. Whether
you and I can do it by mail or whether I can get to Havana in December remains
to be seen but certainly we can discuss it three weeks from now in Philadelphia
and may I suggest that you discuss my letter frankly with Doctor Recio if you
think that wise now. Make your own list of your own ideas for Camp Lazear and
we will match our lists in Philadelphia.

I don't plan to arrive in Philadelphia until noon on September 22 and plan to
leave the afternoon of the 23rd. Why don't you and I disappear after the
evening meeting of the 22nd. We could do a lot together in two hours, even
if we have to stay up after midnight. Or, if absolutely necessary, I could
get to Philadelphia, somehow, earlier in the morning of the 22nd and hide out
with you that morning. My absence-time for the rest of this year is quite
limited and every half day I am away is counted, but if you think we can dis-
cuss this satisfactorily late Thursday evening, the 22nd, I will try to do
whatever you propose.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH: alo
Dr. Pedro Nogueira - 6 September 2, 1955
P.S.: I enclose a copy of this letter in case you wish to show it to Doctor
Recio. I want it distinctly understood that if he did not know of any of this
talk and informal thinking and planning, I assumed that you knew it and what-
ever I had not told you was simply because it was still all in such a nebulous
stage and under no circumstances were any plans of mine at least being made
that would not have been brought, at the appropriate time, for the considera-
tion of the Patrons. Whatever rumors or remarks otherwise you hear do not
come from me, have no connection with me and do not have my approval. I
imagine someone, not knowing how close you and I have been working and how
greatly I feel indebted to Doctor Recio and his associates. Someone who has
heard of the informal conversations mentioned above has simply “talked big”,
a sort of wishful thinking, and that is all there is to the rumors you have
heard.
P.P.S: I am so frank about this that if you want an extra copy of this
letter for anyone else, let me know and we will send it to you.
Sincerely,
P. S. Hench, M.D.
